Zidong Wei is Professor in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University. He received Bachelor degree from Shaanxi University of Science & Technology (1984), and Ph.D. degree from Tianjin University (1994). He has been in the field of electrochemical catalysis for more than 30 years and has published more than 300 papers with citation over 22000 times. He has been the Chief Scientist of the National Key Research and Development Program and the Chief Scientist of the National Natural Science Foundation. He edited or participated in the compilation of “Electrochemical Catalysis”, “Chemical Process Intensification”, “Electrocatalysis”, “Electrocatalytic Oxygen Reduction Reaction” and other books. He won the first, second and third prizes of provincial and ministerial level natural sciences and technological progress once each. He is a council member in the Chemical Industry and Engineering Society of China, and Chinese Chemical Society. item S1872-2067(23)64427-4 S1872206723644274 1-s2.0-S1872206723644274 Review Carbon-based catalysts of the oxygen reduction reaction: Mechanistic understanding and porous structures Wenjing Zhang Jing Li * Zidong Wei * a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 401331 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, China * Corresponding author. Carbon-based catalysts are potential substitutes for noble-metal catalysts in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) owing to their excellent electrical conductivities and chemical stabilities. To rationally design and accelerate the identification of highly efficient carbon-based ORR catalysts, improving the design of the active sites and microstructures is necessary. In this review, strategies for improving the intrinsic performances, activities, stabilities, and anti-poisoning properties of catalysts are analyzed. As a critical component of the microstructure, the porous structures of catalysts significantly affect their distributions of active sites and levels of mass transfer, which are also extensively analyzed. Finally, based on the formation of active sites and the fabrication of porous structures, conclusions and perspectives regarding the future development of highly efficient carbon-based electrocatalysts are provided. Graphical Abstract This review systematically summarizes the strategies to regulate the intrinsic activity of the catalytic sites as well as the routes to construct micro-, meso- and macro-porous structures, for enhancing the performances of carbon-based catalysts in oxygen reduction reaction. Keywords Carbon-based catalyst Oxygen reduction reaction Active site Porous structure Electrocatalyst 1 Introduction Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) attract considerable attention because of their high conversion efficiencies and specific energies and low degrees of environmental pollution, and they may be widely used in vehicles, such as automobiles and airplanes, and stationary power stations [1–3]. Cathodic and anodic electrochemical catalytic processes in membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) mainly comprise unit steps, such as liquid-phase mass transfer, species adsorption and desorption, electron transfer, and surface transformation at the electrode interface in series. Electrochemical catalysis is a complex system that includes multiple spatiotemporal scales [4–7]: electron transfer at the quantum scale, active sites at the atomic scale, the triple phase boundary and electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) mechanism at the molecular level, catalyst and proton conductors at the nanometer scale, the catalytic layer and MEA at the micrometer scale, and the fuel cell stack at the meter scale (Fig. 1 ). Each scale may significantly affect the electrochemical ORR and cell performance, and thus, a deep understanding of the characteristics and behavior at each scale is key in considerably enhancing electrocatalytic performance [8–11]. Catalyst design at the nanometer scale attracts significant attention. Depending on whether they contain metallic species, carbon-based catalysts may be classified as metal-containing or -free. A remarkable investigation of metal-free carbon-based ORR electrocatalysts was reported by Dai et al. [12] in 2009, who determined that N-doped carbon nanotube (CNT) arrays exhibit strong electrocatalytic activities in the ORR in alkaline environments. N-doped graphene was subsequently reported as a metal-free ORR catalyst [13]. Thereafter, a range of heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts was reported, which accelerated research progress in this field. Additionally, based on these metal-free carbon materials, several profound insights into ORR processes have been reported, including the locations of the active sites of the doped catalysts, the electrolyte pH dependency of ORR activity, and factors influencing stability [14]. Compared to those of metal-free carbon-based catalysts, metal-based catalysts exhibit enhanced ORR activities. Metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N/C) and metal-carbide (M3C) catalysts attract special attention because of their high ORR activities. The exploitation of M-N/C dates back to 1964, when Jasinski et al. [15] reported the use of cobalt phthalocyanine in the electrochemical ORR in alkaline media. In 1976, Jahnke et al. [16] reported significant progress in this field, with the ORR activities and stabilities of the metal macrocyclic catalysts improving considerably after calcination. In 1989, Yeager et al. [17] reported that the heating of a mixture containing a metal precursor and carbon support and an N-containing polymer yielded a product with an ORR catalytic activity comparable to that of the catalyst obtained via the pyrolysis of metal macrocycles. Since then, numerous excellent M-N/C catalysts have been synthesized, and their ORR activities far surpass those of commercial Pt/C catalysts, particularly in alkaline solutions. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become increasingly common. Zhang et al. [18] first reported single Pt atoms in 2011, paving the way for the rapid development of SACs. Various SACs, including Fe-based [19,20], metallic (Pd-Pt)-carbon nitride (Pd (Pt)-C3N4) [21,22], bimetallic [23–25], and metal/N-doped graphene SACs [26–28], have been widely utilized in different catalytic systems with exceptional performances. With respect to the remarkable progress in the field of carbon-based ORR catalysts, this review outlines recent developments in this field. First, the ORR mechanism is briefly introduced, followed by an analysis of the challenges in the field of carbon-based catalysts. Subsequently, we present strategies for designing and introducing active sites, enhancing catalyst stability, and fabricating porous structures in carbon-based catalysts. Finally, based on the above analysis, the conclusions and outlook are provided. 2 ORR mechanism The ORR comprises two main pathways: 4e– and 2e– processes [29–31]. The 4e– pathway generates OH– in alkaline media and H2O in acidic media, whereas the 2e– pathway generates intermediate species of H2O2. As a strong oxidant and corrosive agent, H2O2 oxidizes and corrodes the cathode catalyst and electrode surface, considerably reducing the cell life, and thus, the 4e– process is preferred over the 2e– process. However, the reaction pathways often include both, leading to complex multielectron reduction processes. Currently, the most studied ORR mechanisms include the following three pathways (Fig. 2(a) ): (1) ORR 4e– dissociative pathway: O2 is strongly adsorbed at the active sites, and the O–O bonds of O2,ad (ad represents adsorption) are cleaved to generate the intermediate species Oad, which is further protonated to form OHad. OH– is formed in alkaline media, and H2O is formed in acidic media. (2) ORR 4e– association pathway: The strong interaction between O2 and the active sites generates O2,ad. The O–O bond is then cleaved after protonation of O2,ad to form the intermediate species OOHad. Subsequently, the Oad species is formed, and the reaction pathway follows that of (1). (3) ORR 2e– pathway: The O–O bond of OOHad generated via pathway (2) is not cleaved but H2O2 products are formed via further protonation. In addition, the reaction pathway on a catalyst surface is closely related to the adsorption strength of the key intermediate species (such as O2,ad, OOHad, OHad, and Oad). Nørskov et al. [32] identified a volcanic relationship between the ORR activities and binding energies of oxygen-containing species on most metal surfaces. As shown in Fig. 2(b), when the ORR intermediate species Oad is strongly adsorbed at the active sites, the corresponding intermediate species or products (Oad and OHad) may not be desorbed, inhibiting the subsequent reaction. When the adsorption of the ORR intermediate species on the surface of the catalyst is too weak, the O2 molecule may not be adsorbed, or the O–O bond may not be activated after adsorption. Therefore, an appropriate interaction strength should be established in the ideal ORR catalyst. In addition to metal-containing catalysts, metal-free materials exhibit volcanic relationships with ORR intermediates. As shown in Fig. 2(c), N- and B-doped graphene are the closest to the peak of the volcano plot, i.e., the binding to OOH is neither too strong nor too weak. Thus, N- or B-doping may produce a superior ORR activity than that obtained via O-, P-, or S-doping [29,33–35]. 3 Limitations of carbon-based electrocatalysts in the ORR Although a range of carbon-based catalysts has been thoroughly investigated, their performances remain inferior to those of Pt-based catalysts, which may be ascribed to their lower intrinsic activities and densities of active sites and inferior stabilities. (1) Low intrinsic activity. As shown in Figs. 2b and 2c, non-precious metal materials are typically located farther from the summit of the volcano than the Pt-group metals, indicating the lower intrinsic activities of the non-precious metal catalysts. (2) Low-density active site dispersion. Typically, pyrolysis is used to prepare carbon-based catalysts, which frequently leads to low-density dispersion of the active sites, e.g., the numbers of active sites per square nanometer in Pt-based catalysts are approximately 10 times those in carbon-based catalysts. For the M-N-C catalyst, the metal loading is generally very low to avoid metal agglomeration and improve the dispersion of active sites, resulting in a lower active site density. Therefore, the thickness of the non-noble metal catalyst layer should be several or even ten times that of the Pt-based catalyst layer to realize a cell power equivalent to that of the cell containing the Pt-based catalyst (Fig. 3 ). A catalyst layer that is too thick may cause a large mass transfer resistance, resulting in additional problems, such as an uneven distribution of H2O vapor, increased internal resistance, flooding, and a rapid degradation in battery performance [36]. (3) The poor stability is likely caused by the loss of active sites, microporous flooding, and catalyst poisoning. In metal-free carbon-based catalysts, the protonation of N in an acidic environment [37] and the oxidation of the active sites under cathodic high-potential conditions [38] may cause considerable activity decay. Demetallation [39] and oxidation [38] of metal atoms are the main causes of the deactivation of metal-containing carbon catalysts. In addition, most carbon-based materials contain numerous micropores. When flooding occurs within the micropores, the O2 supply to the active sites is interrupted, which then terminates the ORR and continuous operation of the fuel cell [40]. Furthermore, trace amounts of impurities, such as SO x [41], CO [42,43], NO x [44,45], and PO x [46], may poison catalysts. 4 Fabrication of the active sites The sites that adsorb and activate reactant molecules are denoted the active sites of the catalyst. In this section, we list several active-site species in carbon-based ORR catalysts. 4.1 Active sites of metal-involved catalysts Recently, SACs have become a common research topic, and several M-N-C electrocatalysts with M-N x active sites (MSA-N-C) were successfully synthesized. Jiang et al. [47] developed a pore engineering strategy to tune the local coordination of pyridinic N groups to optimize the electronic structures of Fe-N4 moieties (Fig. 4(a) ). The edge-hosted Fe-N4 structure (FeN4-6r-c2), as shown in Fig. 4(b), enables the ready adsorption of ORR intermediates and decreases the energy barriers associated with the entire ORR. However, these methods generally employ high-cost precursors (metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), porphyrin macrocycles, etc.) and involve very complicated post-treatment processes, which considerably hinder the practical application of carbon-based SACs. In contrast, Wei et al. [48] successfully synthesized SACo-N/C catalysts using low-cost urea and glucose as precursors. As shown in Fig. 4(c), Co2+-SCN– decomposition at low temperatures enables the generation of Co-rich particles at temperatures below the carbon deposition temperature, which leads to the formation of Co-rich particles before graphitic carbon deposition. The Co species then diffuse into the carbon layer to form a uniform distribution of metallic Co single atoms. The prepared SACo-N/C catalyst exhibits an improved discharge efficiency compared to that of commercial Pt/C in ZnO2 batteries, indicating a superior ORR performance. Earth-rich materials containing Fe-N-C centers are promising alternatives to Pt catalysts in oxygen reduction (ORR), but these catalysts often feature porphyrin-like FeN4 structures. According to density functional theory (DFT) calculations, FeN2 may outperform FeN4 because of its faster electron transport and weaker interactions with intermediates, such as *O2 and *OH. Shen et al. [49] introduced atomically scattered FeN2 sites on an N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon surface for the first time, using a hard template route (Figs. 5(a–i) ). Strong anchoring between the hard template SBA-15 and metal sites prevents the migration of metallic Fe, resulting in the successful preparation of single-Fe-atom catalysts with very high ORR half-wave potentials (E 1/2). In addition to SACs, bimetallic-atom electrocatalysts received extensive attention recently. By carefully regulating the atomic-scale structures of bimetal-organic frameworks prior to pyrolysis, Xiao et al. [50] generated an innovative binuclear active site structure, Co2N5, to effectively catalyze oxygen reduction (Fig. 5(j)). Comparing it with Co nanoparticles and CoN4 SACs reveals that an order-of-magnitude increase in C2N5 mass activity is realized. Further computational results indicate that the dual-site catalyst aids in altering the reaction pathway and thus significantly enhances the ORR performance. In addition to single atoms, embedding nanoclusters and -particles into carbon materials may also yield active sites. Recently, Hong et al. [51] reported the preparation of ultrasmall atomic clusters supported on 3D porous carbon aerogels via the self-assembly of graphene oxide with g-C3N4 and iron phthalocyanine under high-temperature and -pressure conditions. The monodisperse FeN x atomic clusters significantly increased the electrochemically active specific surface area and provided an excellent oxygen reduction activity and stability. He et al. [52] produced CNTs containing FeN x active sites (denoted FeN x -CNTs) by pyrolyzing zeolitic imidazole framework-8 doped with Fe sources (Fe-ZIF). In PEMFCs and their anion exchange counterparts, this cathode catalyst exhibits extraordinarily high peak power densities of 1.16 and 1.15 W cm–2, respectively, which are significant breakthroughs at the device level. 4.2 Active sites of metal-free catalysts Metal-free carbon nanomaterials attract considerable interest owing to their low costs, facile syntheses, environmental benignities, good conductivities, large surface areas, and uninhibited electron motion [53,54]. Heteroatom doping (B, N, O, S, P, etc.) may be the most direct and efficient strategy for introducing active sites into carbon materials [55]. Wei et al. [56] used layered montmorillonite (MMT) with an interlayer thickness of < 1 nm as a nanoreactor in the selective syntheses of pyridinic and pyrrolic N-doped graphene catalysts (Fig. 6(a) ). When MMT with an interval width of 0.46 nm is used, the N contents within the prepared catalysts (NG@H-MMT) are as high as 90.27%. In a 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solution, the E 1/2 of NG@H-MMT is only 60 mV less than those of the most advanced commercial Pt/C catalysts. Additionally, NG@H-MMT displays an exceptional methanol tolerance, along with a high durability and selectivity toward the ORR. To reconsider the ORR catalytic nature and identify universal descriptors that define the catalytic activities of carbon atoms, Wei et al. [57] conducted a thorough examination of heteroatom-doped graphene using DFT calculations. As shown in Figs. 6(b–e), the intrinsic activities and mechanisms at the carbon sites may be affected by the triple effect: charge, spin, and coordination. The triple effect effectively integrates the effects of charge, spin density, and ligand environment on the ORR catalytic activities of the carbon active sites of doped graphene. Therefore, the oxygen reduction catalytic performances of the internal carbon active sites may be predicted and extrapolated well. 5 Enhancement of catalyst stability In strong acid/alkali electrolytes, the high potential applied at the electrode surface may induce the leaching and oxidation of metal atoms, resulting in the loss of active sites in carbon-based catalysts. In addition, several small molecules may degrade the catalytic stabilities by poisoning the catalysts. This section provides a brief analysis of the strategies for improving electrochemical stability and anti-poisoning character. 5.1 Electrochemical stability Fe-N-C is a highly active, unstable ORR catalyst, particularly in acidic solutions, but its deactivation mechanism remains unclear. Wei et al. [58] investigated the possible mechanism of Fe-N-C degradation during ORR catalysis using DFT and proposed a competing relationship between Fe oxidation and ORR catalysis at the active site (Fig. 7(a) ). Using the FeN4 moiety as an active site renders N protonation of bare Fe-N-C unfavorable. Instead, the Fe sites are easily oxidized to form *Fe(OH)2 during the ORR. After 2OH* species are adsorbed on Fe on the same side of the FeN4 plane, N species may be continuously protonated, which then leads to the leaching of the Fe sites and a rapid decrease in the ORR activity. When 2OH* species are adsorbed on opposite sides of the FeN4 plane, the Fe active site is blocked rather than leached. Therefore, demetallation of the Fe-N-C catalyst is the most critical underlying cause of activity decay in an acidic medium. Wei et al. [59] reported an atomically dispersed Zn-N-C catalyst with an ultrahigh Zn loading of 9.33 wt%. In acidic and alkaline environments, the ORR activity and stability of the Zn-N-C catalyst are equivalent to those of the Fe-N-C catalysts (Fig. 7(b)). DFT calculations were used to evaluate the anticorrosion properties of the active sites in the Zn-N4 and Fe-N4 structures (Fig. 7(c)). The energy required to convert the Zn sites (*Zn) to *Zn(OH) in the first step is higher than the free energy required to form *Fe(OH). Furthermore, the transition from *Zn(OH) to *Zn(OH)2 in the second step is almost impossible because of the high free energy, whereas the production of *Fe(OH)2 from *Fe(OH) is viable because of the lower free energy. Therefore, the use of metallic Zn as the active centers in non-precious metal-carbon-based catalysts should result in superior stabilities, particularly in PEMFCs. 5.2 Anti-poisoning One of the most crucial factors affecting the degradation of catalyst performance is poisoning. Even a very small number of toxic species may cause sudden reductions in performance. Air pollutants, including SO x , CO, NO x , salt aerosols, and PO x , are the main poisoning species of carbon-based ORR catalysts [60]. In high-temperature PEMFCs that commonly use polybenzimidazole membranes doped with H3PO4, PO4 3– adsorption on Pt may drastically reduce the catalytic activity and overall cell performance [61–64]. Hu et al. [65] reported that PO4 3– anions exhibit negligible poisoning effects on the activity of an Fe-N-C catalyst (Figs. 8(a–d) ). Wei et al. [66] reported significant advancements in the design of high-performance, anti-poisoning, carbon-based catalysts. They prepared N- and P-doped porous carbon ORR catalysts via self-assembly (Fig. 8(e)). In the catalyst poisoning studies of N- and P-doped carbon (NC and PC) and Pt/C, introducing very small amounts of SO x , NO x , and PO x anions into the electrolyte significantly decreases the ORR activities. The activity attenuations of NC, PC, and Pt/C are the highest during SO x poisoning, whereas no distinct E 1/2 attenuation is observed when using N and P co-doped carbon (PNC), indicating an excellent anti-poisoning stability (Figs. 8(f) and 8(g)). The simulation results show that P doping of N-C promotes the production of O-bonded carbon atoms, thus strengthening the structural stability. This study provides a novel method of designing anti-poisoning ORR electrocatalysts. 6 Fabrication of the porous structure In low-temperature fuel cells, the ORR occurs at triple phase boundaries, where electrons and protons react with O2 to produce H2O [67]. Traditional catalysts display limited specific surface areas, which result in low usage efficiencies of the active sites. A well-designed porous structure, such as interconnected hierarchical pores, may enable the rapid penetration of the electrolyte and smooth transfer of ions and O2 for an enhanced ORR activity [68]. In this section, we present the main strategies for fabricating micro- (pore diameter < 2 nm), meso- (2 nm < pore diameter < 50 nm), and macroporous (pore diameter > 50 nm) carbon-based electrocatalysts and briefly analyze the relationship between the porous structure and ORR performance. 6.1 Micropores In commonly used amorphous carbon supports, the sizes of the primary carbon particles are approximately tens of nanometers, and numerous micropores are present. These particles are aggregated via van der Waals forces, and the gaps between the particles form mesopores, with the further accumulation of clusters producing large pores. Shui et al. [69] proposed that in this structure, although mesopores could be used as a mass transfer channel for gas diffusion to the micropores, the high tortuosities of the mesopores resulted in a large mass transfer resistance within a cluster. Mesopores exhibit much higher volume/specific surface area ratios than those of micropores. Therefore, the presence of mesopores increases the macroscopic volume of the catalyst and decreases the bulk current density of the electrode. In addition, oxidation and corrosion of primary carbon particles occur during the operation of the fuel cell, interrupting the electronic transmission between particles and increasing the overall impedance of the cell. Based on these factors, they suggested that the ideal catalyst design should display a compact distribution of micropores containing active sites, and the reactants/products should travel directly to and from the active sites through the large pores to minimize mass transfer resistance while avoiding the mesoporous sites. Accordingly, they prepared a fibrous Fe-N-C catalyst via electrostatic spinning (Fig. 9(a) ). The interwoven nanofibers form large pores for mass transfer, and the surfaces of the fibers are covered with densely distributed micropores containing catalytic sites. The catalyst displays a very high specific activity in a single-cell study. Lefevre et al. [70] reported that the activities of Fe-based catalysts in the ORR are not comparable to those of Pt catalysts, owing to their relatively small numbers of active sites per unit volume. They designed and prepared Fe-based catalysts using microporous carbon supports. The active Fe cations are coordinated by pyridinic N centers located between the graphitic sheets within the micropores. Heating carbon black, phenanthroline, and ferrous acetate under Ar and NH3 significantly increases the density of the active sites. At a cell potential of 0.9 V, the current density is equivalent to that of a Pt-based cathode loaded with 0.4 mg Pt cm–2 (Fig. 9(e)). In addition to the use of spatial confinement to generate microporous structures, salt-template-assisted methods have also been widely used. Zhang et al. [71] synthesized N-doped carbon with a large specific surface area by calcining a mixture of NaCl and ZIF-8 at high temperatures. After the secondary calcination of microporous carbon with adsorbed Fe3+, Fe SACs with very high active site densities (Fe-N/C-NaCl) were successfully generated (Fig. 9(b)). Although the loading of single-atom Fe is only ~1.3 wt%, the highly microporous structure ensures that all active sites are accessible, which leads to the high power density of the PEMFC. Thus, the specific surface areas of the micropores correlate positively with the active site density and ORR performance (Figs. 9c and 9d)). 6.2 Mesopores Micropores mainly serve as hosts of the carbon-based active sites. In comparison, mesopores with larger pore sizes may simultaneously function as the mass transfer channels of the reactant, O2, and product, H2O [72]. To date, various strategies have been developed to fabricate ordered or randomly distributed mesopores in carbon-based ORR catalysts. 6.2.1 Template method Hard and soft template methods have been widely used in synthesizing ordered mesoporous materials. Uniform SiO2 and polystyrene microspheres are the most common hard template materials. As the hard template method exhibits no special requirements for the force between the precursor and template, it is particularly suitable in preparing ordered mesoporous structures that are challenging to synthesize using the sol-gel process. Liang et al. [73] prepared three Co-N/C electrocatalysts with well-tuned morphologies and porous structures using three different hard porous templates (Figs. 10(a–d) ). Among those of the prepared catalysts, the largest specific surface area is 568 m2 g–1, with an average mesopore size of 12 nm. This catalyst exhibits a remarkable ORR activity and high selectivity and an excellent electrochemical stability in acidic media. Lu et al. [74] also synthesized mesoporous N-doped carbon spheres with diameters of 200–600 nm using SiO2 colloids as templates. The porous carbon spheres displayed ultrahigh specific surface areas and a uniformly distributed mesoporous pore size (15 nm). Abundant mesopores facilitate the timely transfer of reactants to active sites, leading to an impressive ORR activity and stability. In addition to the most common SiO2 template, metallic oxides are often used as reactive hard templates in preparing mesoporous materials. Wang et al. [75] used Fe3O4 nanocubic superlattices as templates to generate atomically dispersed Fe sites anchored on cubic nanoframework catalysts (Fig. 10(e)). With completely accessible active sites and significantly enhanced mass transfer efficiencies, the Fe-N-C catalysts exhibit ORR activities comparable to that of commercial Pt/C in Zn-air batteries. Similarly, Ma et al. [76] used ZnO nanofibers as templates to produce Fe-N x active site-modified CNTs via the adsorption of Fe3+ on the surfaces, coating with polydopamine, pyrolysis in an NH3 atmosphere, and the removal of the ZnO templates at a high temperature (Fig. 10(f)). The volatilization of Zn during pyrolysis produces numerous micropores in the CNTs, resulting in highly exposed inner surfaces, which effectively improves the ORR activity of the catalyst. Compared with the hard template route, the soft template method displays more advantages in synthesizing ordered mesoporous structures. Mun et al. [77] synthesized a mesoporous m-FePhen-C catalyst using a unique soft template method, and the catalyst exhibits an improved ORR performance compared to that of Pt/C in half-cell studies (Fig. 11(a) ). In the MEA, the power density of the m-FePhen-C cathode is 40% higher than that of the commercial Pt/C cathode. Wei et al. [78] used F127 as a soft template in developing a novel type of highly efficient 3D porous Fe/N/C electrocatalyst (Fig. 11(b)). The synthesized catalyst displays an interconnected, hollow, open structure, with an extraordinarily high ORR activity, stability, and selectivity under alkaline and acidic conditions. Tan et al. [79] synthesized Fe-N/C catalysts with ordered mesopores using F127 as a soft template. Electrochemical studies revealed that the catalytic activity increased with increasing mesopore content, and a properly balanced Fe content and specific surface area led to a superior ORR activity. The ORR followed a 4e– transfer process in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, and the electrocatalytic stability and methanol resistance were excellent. 6.2.2 Self-template method based on MOFs As highly crystalline porous materials, MOFs are characterized by homogeneous pore structures, physicochemical properties, and periodic arrangements of metal sites and organic ligands, enabling the precise design and syntheses of a series of functional materials based on MOF materials. The advantages of MOFs in the field of catalysis are as follows: (1) the cavities within the material render a MOF an ideal host material that may encapsulate guest molecules, which is critical in preparing catalysts with specific compositions; (2) the high porosity of a MOF results in MOF derivatives with high surface areas and porous structures, and its uniform structure also ensures the uniform distribution of active sites throughout the structure. A typical template method requires a certain interaction between the template and precursor to form mesoporous structures, which, to a certain extent, limits the use of the method. In the MOF-self-template route, the MOFs contain the precursor species, which considerably simplifies the preparation and may lead to additional materials that may not be synthesized via the template method. Wei et al. [80] developed hierarchically porous Fe-N-C nanotube catalysts by employing Fe-citrate and ZIF-8 as precursors (Figs. 12(a–c) ). The tube structure facilitates mass transfer and exposure of the active sites. The resultant Fe-N-CNTs exhibit remarkable electrocatalytic performances comparable to those of commercial standards because of the completely utilized active sites in the interior and exterior walls of the CNTs. In addition, they [81] developed a carbon-based catalyst, wherein CNTs were formed vertically on carbide metal oxide nanosheets (Fig. 12(d)). Owing to its distinct hierarchical porous structure, the catalyst displays a very high electrochemical surface area, relatively low charge transfer resistance, and rapid mass transfer. Additionally, the assembled Zn-air battery exhibits a particularly high power density and an excellent stability (Figs. 12(e) and 12(f)). Hollow structures may also be fabricated to increase the specific surface areas of catalytic materials. Rich, diverse multistage porous materials may be designed by adjusting the internal space and porous structure of the shell. Wei et al. [82] fabricated a hollow structure based on a stress-induced orientation contraction mechanism for the first time (Fig. 13(a) ). With an increase in the calcination temperature, the material gradually evolves from a solid structure to a core-shell structure with a small interior hollow and an interlayer, and then to the final dodecahedral hollow structure. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) reveals that the generated NC15~900 exhibits an E 1/2 of 0.848 V during the ORR in an alkaline system. The kinetic exchange current density reaches 20.3 mA cm–2 at 0.8 V, and the catalytic performance is significantly superior to that of commercial Pt/C (Figs. 13(b) and 13(c)). The micro- and mesopores in the shell facilitate the exposure of the active sites, and the large cavity generated by the hollow structure significantly improves the mass transfer efficiency. 6.2.3 Molten salt-facilitated method As the molten salt acts as an invisible reactor during the reaction, shielding the active material from loss and forming a series of connected pores via the molten salt phase transition may be viable [83]. Recently, several researchers showed that gas-escape channels may also evolve into porous channels in bulk materials during the transitions from solid and liquid phases to gas phases. Therefore, a series of porous material preparation methods was developed based on high-temperature phase transitions. Using one of these methods, Wei et al. [84] fabricated 3D hierarchically porous carbon (Fig. 14(a) ), which considerably enhances the mass transfer efficiency of the reactant gas and generated water, thus realizing an excellent ORR performance. When preparing metal-N/C catalysts in an open atmosphere, the volatilization of the metal and N may lead to a loss of active species, and thus, a lower active site density in the resultant catalyst, which is not favorable in the ORR. Wei et al. [85] introduced a molten ZnCl2/KCl eutectic salt into the reaction system (Fig. 14(b)), which effectively increases the content of the doped heteroatom N within the generated catalyst. Meanwhile, the volatilization of ZnCl2 salt at a lower temperature results in numerous interconnected micro- and mesopores. The obtained Fe-N/C catalyst displays a yield of as high as 74%, which is significantly higher than those previously reported. In addition, it delivers a high power density in a Zn-O2 battery, representing a superior ORR catalyst (Figs. 14(c–e)). 6.3 Macropores Macropores in electrocatalysts not only improve the exposure of active sites, but also significantly enhance mass transfer. Typically, hard templates and stacking of primary structural units are used in fabricating macroporous electrocatalysts. Lee [86] synthesized FeTMPP-C-500 (diameter: 500 nm) and FeTMPP-C-50 (diameter: 50 nm) using SiO2 microspheres of different sizes as hard templates (Fig. 15(a) ). Although the specific surface area and Fe and N contents of FeTMPP-C-500 (228.1 m2 g–1) are lower than those of FeTMPP-C-50 (468.3 m2 g–1), the half-wave and initial potentials of Fe-TMPP-C-500 in the ORR are higher than those of FETMPP-C-50 (Figs. 15(b) and (c)). The macropores effectively promote mass transfer and improve the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst. Additionally, an in situ solid-phase polymerization strategy was recently reported [87], wherein the polymerization reaction was conducted within a frozen block (Fig. 15(d)). The prepared catalyst exhibits a 3D framework structure with well-linked macropores with sizes in the range 50–200 nm and highly dispersed Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles embedded in the pore walls (Figs. 15(g–j)). The product (FeNC-LP) prepared via traditional liquid-phase polymerization comprises heavily agglomerated nanospheres and -tubes, without a clear porous structure. The FeNC-3 catalyst with a high specific surface area and pore volume delivers a high ORR performance and kinetic current in an alkaline electrolyte (Figs. 15(e) and 15(f)). In contrast, FeNC-LP exhibits a significantly lower catalytic activity, which is due to poor mass transfer caused by the macropore-deficient structure. 7 Conclusions and outlook After decades of research, significant progress has been reported in the field of carbon-based catalysts, and their catalytic performances have surpassed those of commercial Pt/C catalysts. This review summarized the research progress regarding carbon-based catalysts in terms of the fabrication of active sites, catalyst stability, and strategies for forming porous structures. Atomic-scale dispersion and doping are the most used methods in generating active sites in metal-containing carbon-based catalysts. Heteroatomic doping is a common strategy for fabricating active sites in metal-free carbon-based catalysts. We then analyzed the causes of catalyst deactivation and how to improve the stabilities and anti-poisoning properties of the catalysts. Fe loss in acidic electrolytes is the main cause of deactivation of Fe-N-C catalysts. Finally, as the porous structures significantly affect the exposure of the active sites and mass transfer, the effects of the different porous structures on the ORR and the preparation strategies of micro-, meso-, and macroporous carbon materials were reviewed. Despite the remarkable progress in these fields, several significant scientific problems remain unresolved. (1) The activities of carbon-based catalysts in acidic solutions are insufficient. Under alkaline conditions, the onset and half-wave potentials of a carbon-based catalyst are higher than those of the commercial Pt/C catalyst, and the gap is slightly wider under acidic conditions. Meanwhile, metallic electrodes often display smaller double-layer currents than those of porous carbon catalysts, particularly when the catalyst loading is high, which may affect the measured diffusion-limiting current. (2) The relationships between the porosity parameters and mass transfer are unclear, e.g., the larger the macropores are, the more efficient the mass transfer is. However, due to the decrease in the volume density of active sites, the thickness of the catalytic layer of the MEA should be increased to ensure that the electrode contains sufficient active sites, which may affect mass transfer. Therefore, determining the sizes of the macropores is necessary to balance rapid mass transfer and a high volume density of active sites. (3) Regarding the reaction pathway, a more in-depth understanding of the mechanisms of the ORR and inactivation of the active sites and design principle of the pore structure is required. Most decay mechanisms are proposed based on simulations or ex situ methods, and thus, further research based on experimental investigations and in situ methods is desirable. (4) Further improvements in the long-term durabilities of metal-containing carbon-based catalysts are required. In the ORR, transition metals, such as M x+ (intermediate valence of transition metal) generated during the reaction, may display very high catalytic activities and incomplete coordination ions. Thus, a very small amount may considerably poison the electrode and electrolyte membrane, degrading cell stability. Catalyst stability is one of the most critical considerations for fuel cells. Thus, the development of carbon-based ORR electrocatalysts is crucial, and this review should be helpful to researchers in related fields. References 1 K. Jiao J. Xuan Q. Du Z.M. Bao B.A. Xie B.W. Zidong Wei is Professor in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University. He received Bachelor degree from Shaanxi University of Science & Technology (1984), and Ph.D. degree from Tianjin University (1994). He has been in the field of electrochemical catalysis for more than 30 years and has published more than 300 papers with citation over 22000 times. He has been the Chief Scientist of the National Key Research and Development Program and the Chief Scientist of the National Natural Science Foundation. He edited or participated in the compilation of “Electrochemical Catalysis”, “Chemical Process Intensification”, “Electrocatalysis”, “Electrocatalytic Oxygen Reduction Reaction” and other books. He won the first, second and third prizes of provincial and ministerial level natural sciences and technological progress once each. He is a council member in the Chemical Industry and Engineering Society of China, and Chinese Chemical Society. Jing Li received her B.A. degree from Tianjin University in 1999, and Ph.D. degree from National University of Singapore in 2008. After postdoctoral research at the Fudan University, she joined the faculty of Tongji University as an associate professor in 2011 and Chongqing University as a professor in 2014. She has been in charge of 2 National Key Research and Development Program of China and 3 National Natural Science Foundation of China. Her research interests include porous materials, fuel cells and electrocatalysis. She has published more than 80 papers with citation over 8000 times.

coredata.dc:description: Carbon-based catalysts are potential substitutes for noble-metal catalysts in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) owing to their excellent electrical conductivities and chemical stabilities. To rationally design and accelerate the identification of highly efficient carbon-based ORR catalysts, improving the design of the active sites and microstructures is necessary. In this review, strategies for improving the intrinsic performances, activities, stabilities, and anti-poisoning properties of catalysts are analyzed. As a critical component of the microstructure, the porous structures of catalysts significantly affect their distributions of active sites and levels of mass transfer, which are also extensively analyzed. Finally, based on the formation of active sites and the fabrication of porous structures, conclusions and perspectives regarding the future development of highly efficient carbon-based electrocatalysts are provided.

coredata.dc:title: Carbon-based catalysts of the oxygen reduction reaction: Mechanistic understanding and porous structures
